ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Best course in developing me as a writer that I've ever taken.

Thinking analytically and really focusing on making original insights in my writingusually, I feel as if I say a lot of nothing, but this course really whipped me into shape. Not to mention, of course, the specific content of the course. A lot of interesting and difficult questions surfaced in our readings and discussions, which made me reconsider the nature of memorialization, the nature of victim/perpetrator labeling, and so much more.
Greatly improved my writing and analysis skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Small class environment, lots of time to meet with the professor, lots of improvement in the quality of my work 
Weaknesses: lots of reading and due date for assignments is usually on Sundays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, as long as you're willing to do the work to get out of it what the class offers.

I highly recommend this course! Though it's difficult at times to grapple with the content of the course (intellectually and emotionally) I feel that what I've learned from this class I'll carry with me for a very long time.
I would definitely recommend this course to other people. It is a challenging course but you leanr a lot and see yourself improve over the semester.
